Interest accrues daily. Paying late or taking an extension increases the amount of interest that will accrue, while principal and early payments decrease that amount.
What are the restrictions on changing my due date?
Changing your due date will result in additional accrued interest.
Do nothing and pay at the end
What are the restrictions on changing my due date?
We allow you to move your due date back a maximum of 15 days from your original due date. Over the course of your loan, you can change your due date 3 times, but the 15 day limit still applies.

Because interest accrues daily, when you make your payment really makes a difference even if it's just a day or two. A general rule for saving money on a loan is - the faster you pay down your balance, the less interest you'll pay.

label.v1: This consent for electronic delivery applies to all required disclosures regarding all accounts you have with Capital One Auto Finance (“we,” “us,” or “Capital One”)®, a division of Capital One, N.A., and is effective until withdrawn by you. Agreeing to accept disclosures electronically means that once we present them to you, and if necessary, you click to accept them, they will apply to you and your accounts with us.
to make sure you can view/print statements.

Electronic acceptance of disclosures means that Capital One will not mail them to you unless requested by you at a later date. To request a hard copy of a disclosure or to have all future disclosures provided to you in hard copy, you may contact us at 1-800-946-0332, or use a method that may be made available to you on this web site. In general, disclosures that are posted to our website will be available to Customers in good standing for 24 months after they are posted. Here is a list of some of the disclosures you may get electronically:
Annual notices re: electronic funds transfers and our Privacy Policy
Any other disclosures that we are required to provide; and
Notices related to any dispute you might raise under the Electronic Funds Transfer Act or Truth in Lending Act.
If Capital One determines that an e-mail message to you regarding any disclosure is undeliverable, we may, at our discretion, choose to mail that disclosure to you using United States mail.

You may withdraw consent for electronic delivery of disclosures, but doing so will not affect the legal effectiveness, validity, or enforceability of electronic records that were made available to you prior to the implementation of your withdrawal. To withdraw consent, or to provide updated information on how Capital One may contact you electronically, you must write to Capital One at P.O. Box 360, Wilmington, DE 19899 or use a method that may be made available to you on this website. If you withdraw consent for electronic delivery, Capital One will provide required disclosures to you using United States mail.
We don't officially support a specific operating system or browser; however, we recommend the following when accessing our site:
Try again. These emails do not match.

When you update your primary email address, we will apply the change to all Capital One accounts that are linked to this user name.  Furthermore, when you provide your email address, we may use it to send you important information about your application and account(s), as well as other useful products and services.
Warning, your account is past due.
You're on track to get current.
Your account is {pasDueDays} day past due.
We understand things happen and we may have a few options to help you get caught up.
This includes your past due amount, any outstanding fees and your next payment that is due on {dueDate}.
Paying your past due amount will bring your account current. Just don't forget to make your next monthly payment on {dueDate}.
If you can't pay the full amount today don't worry, we may have other options to help you get back on track.
What happens if I do nothing?

If your account is past due, you may be assessed late fees and reported to the credit bureaus when your account status reaches 30 days past due.  Your account will also accrue additional interest that you’ll have to pay by the end of your loan.
If your account is 30, 60, or 90 days past due at the end of the month, we will report you as such to the credit agencies.
Are you able to make your minimum required payment?
Are you able to make your minimum required payment of ${monthlyPaymentAmount} {dayDateDescription}?
Making the minimum required payment will reduce your days past due by 1 month. This gets you closer to being caught up on your payments.
Why do I need to make the minimum required payment?
If your account is 30, 60, or 90 days past due at the end of the month, we will report you as such to the credit agencies.
How does this impact my credit?
If so, what day will you make that payment?
Give us a call at 1-800-946-0332 as soon as possible and we'll discuss if there are more options to help you get back on track.
Great! Now let's plan out the rest.
After {firstPaymentDate} payment, we'll divide what is left and add it to your next {numberOfRemainingCatchupPayments} monthly payments.
If everything looks good, next you'll choose the account you'd like to use.
High five! Making this payment will reduce your past due amount.
If everything looks good, next you'll choose the account you'd like to make payments from.
Look over your payments and if everything looks doable, go ahead and submit your plan.

By clicking the "Submit" Payment button, I authorize Capital One to make a one-time debit today, and three recurring payments in the amounts and dates shown above from my account ending on the last date as outlined in my payment summary.
I understand that I have until 5 PM ET on the scheduled payment dates to cancel a payment.
If you have any questions please call us at 1-800-946-0332.
You've submitted {paymentDay} payment and are closer to getting back on track.
You've scheduled your payments and are closer to getting back on track.

Exiting now will cancel this plan and your account will remain past due.

If you need assistance please give us a call at 1-800-946-0332 as soon as possible.
Where would you like to pay from?
Select which account you would like us to use to withdraw your payments.

Making one monthly payment today will move your account from 60 to 30 days past due. This improves what is being reported to the credit bureaus and gets you much closer to being caught up on your payments.
Why should I make one monthly payment?
Whenever your account becomes 30, 60 or 90 days past due we're required to report you as such. Going from 60 to 30 days can lessen the impact to your credit.
Why should I make one monthly payment?

We're currently building a tool that will allow you to break up your past due amount into multiple smaller payments.

In the meantime, give us a call at 1-800-946-0332 and we can set up this plan over the phone or discuss other options you may have.
To take full advantage of the Loan Tracker tool we need to get your account current.
We understand things happen. You can make a payment now or contact us for more options.
Each day your account is past due, you're accruing more and more unnecessary interest. This will impact your loan long term, so the faster you get current, the better.
is your past due amount. Click this link to view Legal Rights and Obligations Disclaimer.
If you're behind on your auto loan account payments, we want to inform you of your legal rights and obligations.

State and Local Disclosures. If you receive this communication in Connecticut, the District of Columbia, Hawaii, Iowa, New York City, North Carolina, or Oregon and your account involves a debt owed primarily for personal, family, household, or other consumer purpose(s), or if you receive this communication in Vermont irrespective of the nature of the debt associated with your account, the following disclosure is required by state or local law: This is an attempt to collect a (consumer) debt (claim). Any information obtained will be used for that purpose.

The following disclosure is required by state law if your account involves a debt owed primarily for personal, family, household, or other consumer purpose(s) and you receive this communication in Hawaii, Iowa, or Oregon. This communication is from a debt collector. The following disclosure is required by state law if your account involves a debt owed primarily for personal, family, household, or other consumer purpose(s) and you receive this communication in Massachusetts: NOTICE OF IMPORTANT RIGHTS: YOU HAVE THE RIGHT TO MAKE A WRITTEN OR ORAL REQUEST THAT TELEPHONE CALLS REGARDING YOUR DEBT NOT BE MADE TO YOU AT YOUR PLACE OF EMPLOYMENT. ANY SUCH ORAL REQUEST WILL BE VALID FOR ONLY 10 DAYS UNLESS YOU PROVIDE WRITTEN CONFIRMATION OF THE REQUEST POSTMARKED OR DELIVERED WITHIN SEVEN DAYS OF SUCH REQUEST. YOU MAY TERMINATE THIS REQUEST BY WRITING TO THE CREDITOR.

This is not a complete list of the rights that you might have. The terms above in this Section are defined by applicable state or local law. Pursuant 15 USC 1692a(6)(B) and (F) of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, Capital One Services, LLC is not a debt collector under federal law. Bankruptcy. If you are entitled to bankruptcy protections for your account, this communication is only for informational purposes. It is not an attempt to collect, assess, or recover a debt or claim. Do not send any payments directly to us without speaking with your attorney or Bankruptcy Trustee.

We calculate the amount left on your loan based on your principal balance, interest rate, and the assumption that you make your payments each month on your due date for the remainder of your loan without additional loan modifications.
Links to Simple Interest Loans: Simplified (Video) on YouTube

Because interest accrues daily, when you make your payment really makes a difference. A general rule for saving money on a loan is - the faster you pay down the total amount you owe, the less interest you'll pay.

Making a payment before your due date, adding a little more to your regular monthly payment each month, or making an additional principal payment will help lower your loan balance faster and reduce the interest that accrues on your loan.
Paying late or taking an extension increases the amount of interest that will accrue. A repeated pattern of late payments makes it more likely that you will owe money at the end of your loan term.
